tasks: Estimates for Stein’s spherical maximal operators
methods: Local smoothing estimates for wave operators
results: Improved estimates for the Lp → Lq boundedness of Stein’s spherical maximal operators
title: L^p→ L^q Estimates for Stein's Spherical Maximal Operators.pdf
abstract: . In this article we consider a modiﬁcation of the Stein’s spherical maximal op- erator of complex order α on Rn: Mα [1,2] f(x) = sup t∈[1,2] 1 Γ(α) Z |y|≤1  1 −|y|2α−1 f(x −ty)dy . We show that when n ≥2, suppose ∥Mα [1,2] f∥Lq(Rn) ≤C∥f∥Lp(Rn) holds for some α ∈C, p, q ≥1, then we must have that q ≥p and Re α ≥σn(p, q) := max ( 1 p −n q, n + 1 2p −n −1 2 1 q + 1 ! , n p −n + 1 ) . Conversely, we show that Mα [1,2] is bounded from Lp(Rn) to Lq(Rn) provided that q ≥p and Re α > σ2(p, q) for n = 2; and Re α > max {σn(p, q), 1/(2p) −(n −2)/(2q) −(n −1)/4} for n > 2. The range of α, p and q is almost optimal in the case either n = 2, or α = 0, or (p, q) lies in some regions for n > 2. 1. Introduction In 1976 Stein [22] introduced the spherical maximal means Mα f(x) = supt>0 |Mα t f(x)| of (complex) order α on Rn, where Mα t f(x) = 1 Γ(α) Z |y|≤1  1 −|y|2α−1 f(x −ty) dy. (1.1) These means are initially deﬁned only for Re α > 0, but the deﬁnition can be extended to all complex α by analytic continuation. In the case α = 1, Mα corresponds to the Hardy- Littlewood maximal operator and in the case α = 0, Mα corresponds to the spherical maximal operator Mf(x) := supt>0 |Mt f(x)| in which Mt f(x) = cn Z Sn−1 f(x −ty) dσ(y), x ∈Rn, (1.2) where Sn−1 denotes the standard unit sphere in Rn. In [22] Stein obtained the inequality ∥Mα f∥Lp(Rn) ≤C∥f∥Lp(Rn) (1.3) for Re α > 1 −n + n/p when 1 < p ≤2; or Re α > (2 −n)/p when 2 ≤p ≤∞. From it, we see that when α = 0 and n ≥3, the maximal operator M is bounded on Lp(Rn) for the range p > n/(n −1). This range of p is sharp, as has been pointed out in [22, 24], no such result can hold for p ≤n/(n −1) if n ≥2. The extension of this result in [22] to the case n = 2 was established about a decade later by Bourgain [2], see also the account in [23, Chapter XI]. In addition to Stein and Bourgain, other authors have studied the spherical maximal means; for instance see [10, 11, 13, 12, 15, 16, 17, 18, 20, 21, 28] and the references therein.
